histogram.name: CopylessPaste.ExtractionFailedUs
histogram.summary:
The time spent on scanning the document in the main frame to extract the metadata. The metadata would be used to feed Icing for CopylessPaste feature on Android. This only counts pages with failed or empty JSON extraction.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: CopylessPaste.ExtractionStatus
histogram.summary: The error status of metadata extraction for AppIndexing.

histogram.name: CopylessPaste.ExtractionUs
histogram.summary:
The time spent on scanning the document in the main frame to extract the metadata. The metadata would be used to feed Icing for CopylessPaste feature on Android. This only counts pages with successful JSON extraction.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: CrashExitCodes.Extension
histogram.summary: The exit codes for crashed extension processes. Note: Due to https://crbug.com/805754, the enum labels are off by 1 for M56 and earlier.

histogram.name: CrashExitCodes.Renderer
histogram.summary: The exit codes for crashed renderer processes. Note: Due to https://crbug.com/805754, the enum labels are off by 1 for M56 and earlier.

histogram.name: Crashpad.CrashReportPending
histogram.summary: The reason that a crash report entered the upload pending state.

histogram.name: Crashpad.CrashReportSize
histogram.summary: The size of a crash report minidump on disk when captured.

histogram.name: Crashpad.CrashUpload.AttemptSuccessful
histogram.summary: Logs whether a crash uploaded succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Crashpad.CrashUpload.Skipped
histogram.summary: The reason that a crash report upload was skipped.

histogram.name: Crashpad.ExceptionCaptureResult
histogram.summary: The outcome of execution of the Crashpad exception handler.

histogram.name: Crashpad.ExceptionCode.Mac
histogram.summary: The exception code encountered in a crash on Mac OS X.

histogram.name: Crashpad.ExceptionCode.Win
histogram.summary: The exception code encountered in a crash on Windows.

histogram.name: Crashpad.ExceptionEncountered
histogram.summary: A count of the number of exceptions handled by Crashpad with two buckets for starting and finishing.

histogram.name: Crashpad.HandlerCrash.ExceptionCode.Mac
histogram.summary: The exception code encountered for a crash of the crash handler process on Mac OS X.

histogram.name: Crashpad.HandlerCrash.ExceptionCode.Win
histogram.summary: The exception code encountered for a crash of the crash handler process on Windows.

histogram.name: Crashpad.HandlerLifetimeMilestone
histogram.summary: Handler start/crash/exit events.

histogram.name: CrashReport.BreakpadIOSUploadOutcome
histogram.summary: Reports the Foundation error code of an attempt to upload a breakpad crash report. "NSNoError" if the upload was successful.

histogram.name: CrashReport.Sender.ActiveRuntime
histogram.obsolete: As of 2020-12, we've decided on a timeout and no longer need this metric.
histogram.summary: The amount of time crash_sender takes to run when invoked directly on Chrome OS, without counting time spent sleeping (e.g. for hold_off_time). Used to make an informed decision about a timeout.

histogram.name: CrashReport.Sender.Runtime
histogram.obsolete: As of 2020-12, we've decided on a timeout and no longer need this metric.
histogram.summary: The amount of time crash_sender takes to run when invoked directly on Chrome OS. Used to make an informed decision about a timeout.

histogram.name: Crypto.TPMSupport
histogram.summary: Collected on Windows at startup. Records whether a TPM is present and, if so, what the best supported algorithm is.

histogram.name: DataPack.Load
histogram.summary: Errors when trying to load DataPack files.

histogram.name: DataUse.AllServicesKB
histogram.summary: The request and response size of the messages exchanged by all the services. Whenever a URLRequest of a service is completed, the number of exchanged bytes is logged in this histogram. The buckets in this histogram are services recorded by the corresponding network traffic annotation tag hashes, so it makes it possible to compare the use of different services in different conditions. Different conditions are added as suffixes to this histogram. If the OS is not Android all the requests are considered foreground.

histogram.name: DataUse.AppTabState
histogram.summary: Records the data use of Chrome user traffic by the foregound vs. background state of the app and tab.

histogram.name: DataUse.BackgroundToDataRecievedPerByte
histogram.summary: The time since Chrome is in background when background data use happens. Recorded for each byte of background data use. The source of traffic whether from user browsing or chrome services is added as suffix to this histogram.

histogram.name: DataUse.BackgroundToFirstDownstream
histogram.summary: The time since Chrome is in background when first background data use happens. Recorded when first background downstream data use after Chrome is in background. The source of traffic whether from user browsing or chrome services is added as suffix to this histogram.

histogram.name: DataUse.BytesReceived
histogram.obsolete: Replaced with DataUse.BytesReceived2 as of 10/2020 to provide more granular buckets above 1 MB
histogram.summary: Count of total bytes received by the Chrome on the network. With network servicification this is recorded when requests complete.

histogram.name: DataUse.BytesReceived2
histogram.summary: Count of total bytes received by the Chrome on the network. This is recorded when requests complete.

histogram.name: DataUse.BytesSent
histogram.summary: Count of total bytes sent by the Chrome on the network. With network servicification this is recorded when requests complete.

histogram.name: DataUse.ContentType.UserTrafficKB
histogram.summary: Data use of user traffic by different content types. Recorded in KB when network bytes are received by Chrome.

histogram.name: DataUse.FavIcon.Downstream
histogram.summary: Records the downstream network data use of favicon requests. Logged when the request is completed or redirected. Zero bytes are recorded when the request is served from cache.

histogram.name: DataUse.FavIcon.Downstream.Non200Response
histogram.summary: Records the downstream network data use of favicon requests with non 200 response code. Logged when the request is completed or redirected.

histogram.name: DataUse.PageTransition.UserTrafficKB
histogram.summary: Data use of user traffic by different core page transition types. Recorded in KB when the URL request finishes.

histogram.name: DataUse.TrafficSize.User
histogram.summary: The total amount of data use of Chrome for user traffic. This traffic has content::ResourceRequestInfo attached to its request. If the OS is not Android all the requests are considered foreground.

histogram.name: DBus.AsyncMethodCallSuccess
histogram.summary: Whether an asynchronous D-Bus method call is successful.

histogram.name: DBus.AsyncMethodCallTime
histogram.summary: The time spent for an asynchronous D-Bus method call.

histogram.name: DBus.ExportedMethodHandleSuccess
histogram.summary: Whether a call to a D-Bus exported method is handled successfully.

histogram.name: DBus.ExportedMethodHandleTime
histogram.summary: The time spent for handling a call to a D-Bus exported method.

histogram.name: DBus.SignalHandleTime
histogram.summary: The time spent for handling a D-Bus signal.

histogram.name: DBus.SignalSendTime
histogram.summary: The time spent for sending a D-Bus signal.

histogram.name: DBus.SyncMethodCallSuccess
histogram.summary: Whether a synchronous D-Bus method call is successful.

histogram.name: DBus.SyncMethodCallTime
histogram.summary: The time spent for a synchronous D-Bus method call.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.ActivateSettings.ErrorHresult
histogram.summary: The HRESULT from ActivateApplication when opening the Win10+ settings page fails.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.InfoBar.UserInteraction
histogram.summary: Possible user interactions with the default browser info bar.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.InteractionResult
histogram.summary: Results of interaction with set-as-default dialog in Win8+ first run flow.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.SetDefaultResult2
histogram.summary: The outcome of an attempt to set Chrome as the user's default browser.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.SettingsInteraction.ConcludeReason
histogram.summary: The reason why the default browser settings interaction concluded on Windows 10.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.SettingsInteraction.RegistryWatcherDuration
histogram.summary: The registry keys for the default browser protocols (http/https) are monitored to know when the user finished interacting with the system settings. This is how long it took for the last registry watcher to get signaled.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.State
histogram.summary:
Whether Chrome was the default browser when it started up.
Only logged correctly on Windows, Mac, and Linux. Logged incorrectly on other platforms.
For ChromeOS, no histogram is necessary because Chrome is always the default browser.
For Android, see Mobile.DefaultBrowser.State.
For iOS, in the future Chrome will be allowed to be the default browser. How that will be logged is to be decided at the time of writing this description.

histogram.name: DefaultBrowser.Win10ChooserInvoked
histogram.summary: When changing the default browser on Windows 10, records whether the browser chooser is successfully invoked when opening the settings page. This histogram is only recorded when the Win10AcceleratedDefaultBrowserFlow experiment is enabled.

histogram.name: DefaultProtocolClient.SetDefaultResult2
histogram.summary: The outcome of an attempt to set Chrome as the user's default client for a protocol.

histogram.name: DemoMode.ActiveApp
histogram.summary: The currently active app or window. Sampled during demo sessions and reported while the user remains active.

histogram.name: DemoMode.AppLaunched
histogram.summary: Records apps that have been launched by a user using the device during Demo mode. The sample is recorded when each app is launched. For any given app id, the metric is recorded only once per Demo Session.

histogram.name: DemoMode.AppLaunchSource
histogram.summary: The source of app launches in demo mode, either the shelf, the app list, or the highlights app.

histogram.name: DemoMode.DwellTime
histogram.summary: The duration the user spent interacting with the demo session, measured from the first user activity to the last user activity. This metric rounds the duration to the nearest second and uses exponential bucketing capped at 1 hour.

histogram.name: DemoMode.IdleLogoutWarningEvent
histogram.summary: Tracks whether the idle logout warning was canceled or proceeded to logout. Note: the count of "shown" includes both cases, so the count of "shown and proceeded" is equal to "shown" minus "canceled".

histogram.name: DemoMode.ResourcesRemoval.Reason
histogram.summary: Tracks the reason for removal of pre-install demo resources. To support offline demo mode, factory Chrome OS devices will have a set of offline enabled demo mode apps pre-installed. These resources are removed once they are not needed anymore.

histogram.name: DemoMode.ResourcesRemoval.Result
histogram.summary: Tracks the result of requests to remove pre-installed demo resources. To support offline demo mode, factory Chrome OS devices will have a set of offline enabled demo mode apps pre-installed. These resources are removed once they are not needed anymore. This will record only requests that attempted deleting pre-installed resources from disk. Requests that fail early will be ignored. For example, a request will fail early if the device is in demo mode, or the resources have already been removed.

histogram.name: DemoMode.SessionLength
histogram.summary: A demo session starts when a user signs in using the policy-configured public account. It stops when the user signs out, either manually or after an idle timeout. Session length is the duration between the start and stop events. It is recorded during signing out and reported on the next chrome run. This metric tracks the recorded session length rounded down to the nearest minute and is capped at 2 hours.

histogram.name: DemoMode.Setup.DownloadDuration
histogram.summary: This records the time taken to download the demo mode resources when demo mode is setup for the first time.

histogram.name: DemoMode.Setup.EnrollDuration
histogram.summary: This records the time taken to enterprise-enroll the device when demo mode is setup for the first time.

histogram.name: DemoMode.Setup.LoadingDuration
histogram.summary: When demo mode is setup for the first time, it must download the demo mode resources and enterprise-enroll the device. This records the time taken for these two steps to complete. (See DemoMode.Setup.DownloadDuration and DemoMode.Setup.EnrollDuration)

histogram.name: DemoMode.Setup.NumRetries
histogram.summary: Records the number of times an operator has encountered an error during the loading screen and been required to retry setup. This is only recorded after setup completes successfully.

histogram.name: DemoMode.UniqueAppsLaunched
histogram.summary: Records how many unique apps have been launched by a user using the device during Demo mode. The sample is recorded when the DemoMode session closes.

histogram.name: Dialog.Create
histogram.summary: Counts the number times dialog boxes are created using a particular parent class.

histogram.name: Dialog.Creation
histogram.summary: Counts the number times various types of dialog boxes are created.

histogram.name: Dialog.DialogDelegate.Duration
histogram.summary: How long dialog boxes are open, for dialog boxes created using the parent class DialogDelegate. This will include bubbles that use BubbleDialogDelegateView as a parent class, and dialogs that use DialogDelegateView as a parent class. This is logged on delegate destruction.

histogram.name: DirectSockets.PermissionDeniedFailures
histogram.summary: Record how often each permission check (e.g. permissions policy, transient activation, user dialog, hostname resolving to non-public address, rate limiting, CORS, enterprise policy) cause Permission Denied failures. Recorded when the permission is denied.

histogram.name: Discarding.DiscardCandidatesCount
histogram.summary: The number of tabs discard candidates. This is recorded each time Chrome needs to urgently discard a tab.

histogram.name: Discarding.DiscardsPer10Minutes
histogram.obsolete: Removed 11/2020. Not actively used because reported values are 0 most of the time. It would be more useful to report number of discards per day.
histogram.summary: Number of tabs discarded in each interval of 10 minutes, per discard reason.

histogram.name: Discarding.HighPMFPolicy.DiscardAttemptsCount
histogram.summary: The number of tab discard attempts during a high-PMF session. Recorded at the end of each high PMF session, or when the number of discard attempts within the same high-PMF session reaches 100 (at which point the counter will reset, e.g. 102 discards attempts would be recorded in two pieces as "100" and "2").

histogram.name: Discarding.HighPMFPolicy.DiscardSuccess
histogram.summary: Indicates if a tab has been successfully discarded during a high-PMF session.

histogram.name: Discarding.HighPMFPolicy.MemoryPressureLevel
histogram.summary: The memory pressure level when the High-PMF policy decides to discard a tab.

histogram.name: Discarding.HighPMFPolicy.MemoryReclaimedKbAfterDiscardingATab
histogram.summary: The amount of memory that has been reclaimed after discarding a tab during a high-PMF session. In the case of a memory increase the value will be reported as 0 and will go in the underflow bucket.

histogram.name: Discarding.HighPMFPolicy.SuccessfulDiscardsCount
histogram.summary: The number of successful tab discards during a high-PMF session. Recorded at the end of each high PMF session, or when the number of successful discards within the same high-PMF session reaches 100 (at which point the counter will reset, e.g. 102 successful discards would be recorded in two pieces as "100" and "2").

histogram.name: Discarding.LargestTabFootprint
histogram.summary: The largest tab's resident set among all the urgent discarding candidates.

histogram.name: Discarding.OldestTabFootprint
histogram.summary: The resident set of the oldest urgent discarding candidate.

histogram.name: Discarding.OnCriticalPressure.TotalRSS_Mb
histogram.obsolete: Removed 03/2021, replaced by Discarding.OnCriticalPressure.TotalRSS_Mb2. The new histogram is now guaranteed to be recorded before discarding any tab.
histogram.summary: An estimate of the total resident set of Chrome when receiving a critical memory pressure event, in megabytes. Note that the estimate is based on the most recent data collected by Performance Manager, which are refreshed at a low frequency (up to 2 minutes).

histogram.name: Discarding.OnCriticalPressure.TotalRSS_Mb2
histogram.summary: An estimate of the total resident set of Chrome when receiving a critical memory pressure event, in megabytes. Note that the estimate is based on the most recent data collected by Performance Manager, which are refreshed at a low frequency (up to 2 minutes).

histogram.name: Discarding.OnCriticalPressure.TotalRSS_PercentOfRAM
histogram.obsolete: Removed 03/2021, replaced by Discarding.OnCriticalPressure.TotalRSS_PercentOfRAM2. The new histogram is now guaranteed to be recorded before discarding any tab.
histogram.summary: An estimate of the total resident set of Chrome when receiving a critical memory pressure event, in percentage of the total amount of RAM. Note that the estimate is based on the most recent data collected by Performance Manager, which are refreshed at a low frequency (up to 2 minutes).

histogram.name: Discarding.OnCriticalPressure.TotalRSS_PercentOfRAM2
histogram.summary: An estimate of the total resident set of Chrome when receiving a critical memory pressure event, in percentage of the total amount of RAM. Note that the estimate is based on the most recent data collected by Performance Manager, which are refreshed at a low frequency (up to 2 minutes).

histogram.name: Discarding.OnlineOnReload
histogram.summary: Whether the machine was online when a discarded tab was reloaded.

histogram.name: Discarding.ReloadsPer10Minutes
histogram.obsolete: Removed 11/2020. Not actively used because reported values are 0 most of the time. It would be more useful to report number of reloads per day.
histogram.summary: Number of discarded tabs reloaded in each interval of 10 minutes, grouped by their discard reason.

histogram.name: Discarding.WinOSPressureSignals.AvailableMemoryMbOnLowMemoryNotification
histogram.summary: The amount of physical memory available when receiving a low memory notification, in megabytes. Windows 8.1+ only.

histogram.name: Discarding.WinOSPressureSignals.LowMemorySessionLength
histogram.summary: The time it takes to receive a high memory notification from the OS after receiving a low memory notification. Windows 8.1+ only.

histogram.name: Discarding.WinOSPressureSignals.PressureLevelOnLowMemoryNotification
histogram.summary: The memory pressure level when receiving a low memory notification from the OS. Windows 8.1+ only.

histogram.name: Display.ParseEdidFailure
histogram.summary: Type of failure that occurs during EDID parsing. Typically the failure is caused by a mismatch between the EDID size and the expected offset of the data component.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.InternalDisplayZoomPercentage
histogram.summary: The zoom percentage that the user has set on the internal display and is actively using. This is emitted when the zoom factor has been updated in display manager and has not been changed for a while.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.MirroringDisplayCountRanges
histogram.summary: The number of displays connected to the device that are in software or hardware mirror mode. This is emitted once when the normal or mixed mirror mode is enabled through API call, or the display configuration changes (e.g. adding or removing a display) when mirror mode is on.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.MirrorModeTypes
histogram.summary: The types of mirror mode in which the displays connected to the device are in. This is emitted once when the normal or mixed mirror mode is enabled through API call, or the display configuration changes ( e.g. adding or removing a display) when mirror mode is on.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.MultiDisplayMode
histogram.summary: The mode in which the connected displays to the device are in. This is emitted once when displays are added or removed, or when the user changes the mode by e.g. enabling mirror or unified modes.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.UnifiedDesktopDisplayCountRange
histogram.summary: The number of displays connected to the device when Unified Desktop mode is on. This is emitted when Unified Desktop mode is turned on, or the displays are added or removed while in Unified Mode.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.UpdateDisplayConfigurationTask.ExecutionTime
histogram.summary: Records the execution time to update the display configuration. Emitted when the update-display-configuration task finishes, successfully or not.

histogram.name: DisplayManager.UpdateDisplayConfigurationTask.Success
histogram.summary: Records whether or not the display configuration was successfully updated. Emitted when the update-display-configuration task finishes, successfully or not.

histogram.name: DNS.PrefetchResolution
histogram.summary: The duration of time used by the DNS pre-resolving threads to resolve a host name via the network. Any resolutions that are faster than 15ms are considered to be local cache hits, not requiring network access, and are not included in this histogram. This histogram is most useful for estimating the typical cost of a name resolution, but it also estimates the total number of network-based resolutions induced by this feature. Not all these resolutions prove helpful (i.e., the user does not always actually visit the resolved hostnames).

histogram.name: DnsProbe.ErrorPageUpdateStatus
histogram.summary: Status of DNS diagnostic probe updates sent to a Chrome net error page.

histogram.name: DnsProbe.ProbeDuration2
histogram.summary: Time ticks between starting and finishing a DNS diagnostics probe.

histogram.name: DnsProbe.ProbeResult
histogram.summary: Result of DNS diagnostics probes sent by the probe service.

histogram.name: Document.BeforeUnloadDialog
histogram.summary: Records result of invoking beforeunload handler, that determines whether to show the dialog.

histogram.name: Document.OutliveTimeAfterShutdown.DestroyedBeforeProcessDies
histogram.summary: Records the GC count between the time when the document is shut down and and the time when the document is actually destroyed. This only counts documents that are destroyed before the process dies.

histogram.name: Document.OutliveTimeAfterShutdown.GCCount
histogram.summary: Records documents that survives some GCs after the document is shut down.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.BeforeUnloadDialogDuration.ByNavigation
histogram.summary: Milliseconds spent in beforeunload dialog. Does not include time to process beforeunload event in JavaScript (see DocumentEventTiming.BeforeUnloadDuration). Recorded immediately after closing dialog, upon user confirmation to navigate away from the page.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.BeforeUnloadDuration
histogram.summary:
Microseconds spent in beforeunload.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.FreezeDuration
histogram.summary:
Microseconds spent in onfreeze.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.PageHideDuration
histogram.summary:
Microseconds spent in pagehide.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.PageVibilityHiddenDuration
histogram.summary:
Microseconds spent in vibilitychange (hidden).
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.ResumeDuration
histogram.summary:
Microseconds spent in onresume.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: DocumentEventTiming.UnloadDuration
histogram.summary:
Microseconds spent in unload.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution. When considering revising this histogram, see UMA_HISTOGRAM_CUSTOM_MICROSECONDS_TIMES for the solution.

histogram.name: DocumentScan.ScanFailed
histogram.summary: Chrome OS document scan metric that tracks which SANE backend (effectively a scanner driver) was used when a scan failed.

histogram.name: DocumentScan.ScanRequested
histogram.summary: Chrome OS document scan metric that tracks which SANE backend (effectively a scanner driver) that a user requested to use for a scan.

histogram.name: DocumentScan.ScanSucceeded
histogram.summary: Chrome OS document scan metric that tracks which SANE backend (effectively a scanner driver) was used when a scan succeeded.

histogram.name: DomainMixing.OneDay
histogram.summary: The distribution over daily active users of Google Search of the ratio of Google searches in the past day that were issued by the user on a Google domain that is not the primary one used by the user over the same time period.

histogram.name: DomainMixing.OneMonth
histogram.summary: The distribution over daily active users of Google Search of the ratio of Google searches in the past 30 days that were issued by the user on a Google domain that is not the primary one used by the user over the same time period.

histogram.name: DomainMixing.OneWeek
histogram.summary: The distribution over daily active users of Google Search of the ratio of Google searches in the past week that were issued by the user on a Google domain that is not the primary one used by the user over the same time period.

histogram.name: DomainMixing.TwoWeeks
histogram.summary: The distribution over daily active users of Google Search of the ratio of Google searches in the past two weeks that were issued by the user on a Google domain that is not the primary one used by the user over the same time period.

histogram.name: Downgrade.CacheDirMove.FailureCount
histogram.summary: The number of items within the Cache directory that could not be moved aside following a downgrade. 0 indicates that the target directory could not be created.

histogram.name: Downgrade.CacheDirMove.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not moving a user's cache dir following a downgrade succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.InvalidSnapshotMove.FailureCount
histogram.summary: The number of items within from an invalid snapshot directory that could not be moved. 0 indicates that the target directory could not be created.

histogram.name: Downgrade.InvalidSnapshotMove.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not moving an invalid snapshot directory succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.RestoreSnapshot.CleanupAfterFailure.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not cleaning up after a snapshot restoration failure succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.RestoreSnapshot.FailureCount
histogram.summary: The number of items within from a snapshot directory that could not be restored following a downgrade.

histogram.name: Downgrade.RestoreSnapshot.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not restoring a snapshot of the user data dir succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.TakeSnapshot.FailureCount
histogram.summary: The number of items within the user data directory that could not be snapshotted following an upgrade.

histogram.name: Downgrade.TakeSnapshot.ItemFailure
histogram.summary: Indicates the id of an item that failed to be copied when taking a user data snapshot.

histogram.name: Downgrade.TakeSnapshot.MoveExistingSnapshot.FailureCount
histogram.summary: The number of items within an existing snapshot directory that could not be moved aside before replacing it with a newer snapshot.

histogram.name: Downgrade.TakeSnapshot.MoveExistingSnapshot.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not moving a user data snapshot dir before replacing it with a newer snapshot succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.TakeSnapshot.ProfileDirectoryCreation.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not creating a profile directory while creating a user data snapshot succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.TakeSnapshot.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not creating a snapshot of the user data dir succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Downgrade.Type
histogram.summary: The type of User Data downgrade detected, if any. The "none" bucket is not reported.

histogram.name: Downgrade.UserDataDirMove.FailureCount
histogram.summary: The number of items within User Data that could not be moved aside following a downgrade.

histogram.name: Downgrade.UserDataDirMove.Result
histogram.summary: Indicates whether or not moving a user's User Data dir following a downgrade succeeded or failed.

histogram.name: Drive.PushNotificationInitiallyEnabled
histogram.summary: Tracks whether the push notification is initially enabled for Drive. Recorded when the first notification is processed. Notification is emulated by polling if the push notication is disabled.

histogram.name: Drive.PushNotificationRegistered
histogram.summary: Tracks whether the push notification request is registered correctly for Drive. Recorded when the push notification manager is initialized.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.Lifecycle.FirstLaunchTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to launch Google Drive for the first time.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.Lifecycle.Mount
histogram.summary: Records outcomes of attempts to mount Google Drive.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.Lifecycle.MountTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to mount Google Drive.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.Lifecycle.Unmount
histogram.summary: Records outcomes of attempts to unmount Google Drive.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.LocalSearch.OfflineSearchTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to perform a lookup of pinned files in local Google Drive cache.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.LocalSearch.SharedSearchTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to perform a search of shared files in local Google Drive cache.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.LocalSearch.TextSearchTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to search a title in local Google Drive cache.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.RemoteSearch.SharedSearchTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to perform a search of shared files in online Google Drive.

histogram.name: DriveCommon.RemoteSearch.TextSearchTime
histogram.summary: How long did it take to perform a search in online Google Drive.

histogram.name: DriveOffline.CrosAutoEnableOutcome
histogram.summary: Outcome of enabling Google Drive offline mode automatically when a user first logs into a Chrome OS device. This process involves opening a hidden web page in the context of the Google Drive hosted app to perform the initialization of offline mode.

histogram.name: DrmUtil.CreateDisplaySnapshot.BitsPerChannel
histogram.summary: Number of bits per channel described by a parsed EDID blob. This UMA is recorded whenever the color space is extracted from an EDID blob.

histogram.name: DrmUtil.CreateDisplaySnapshot.HasEdidBlob
histogram.summary: Whether an EDID blob was detected. This UMA is recorded whenever we attempt to parse the EDID from a display.

histogram.name: DrmUtil.CreateDisplaySnapshot.IsHDR
histogram.summary: Whether a EDID blob contained an HDR transfer function (e.g. SMPT SE2084 or HLG). This UMA is recorded whenever the color space is extracted from an EDID blob.

histogram.name: DrmUtil.GetColorSpaceFromEdid.ChecksOutcome
histogram.summary: When attempting to get the color space from an EDID blob, whether the sanity checks passed (and if not, which check failed). This UMA is recorded whenever the color space is extracted from an EDID blob.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthEvent.DidUserManuallyUnlockPhone
histogram.summary: Upon a successful Smart Lock unlock or signin, records whether the user's phone was locked during any point while the lock screen was up. This can be used to get a sense for whether users are using Smart Lock for Chromebook without something like Smart Lock for Android to keep their phones unlocked.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthEvent.SignIn
histogram.summary: Measures the use of Smart Lock on the sign-in screen: records whether a Smart Lock login succeeded or failed; or if a password fallback was used, the reason why. Recorded upon a login attempt for users who have the Smart Lock feature enabled.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthEvent.SignIn.Duration
histogram.summary: Measures the time elapsed between the user focusing their user pod and signing in using Smart Lock.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthEvent.Unlock
histogram.summary: Measures the use of Smart Lock on the lock screen: records whether a Smart Lock unlock attempt succeeded or failed; or if a password fallback was used, the reason why. Recorded upon an unlock attempt for users who have the Smart Lock feature enabled.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthEvent.Unlock.Duration
histogram.summary: Measures the time elapsed between the lock screen being shown and the user unlocking the device using Smart Lock. The lock screen is typically shown when the user opens their Chromebook's lid (or otherwise wakes the computer), but can also be shown when the user manually locks the device.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthProximity.RemoteDeviceModelHash
histogram.summary: The hash of the phone model used to successfully sign in or unlock using Smart Lock.
histogram.details: This hash is calculated by taking the first 4 bytes of the MD5 hash of the device model.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.AuthProximity.RollingRssi
histogram.summary: Measures the exponentially weighted rolling average of the received signal strength indicator (RSSI) of the phone when the user successfully unlocks or signs in using Smart Lock.
histogram.details:
The exponentially weighted averaging formula is:
rollingRssi = (1 - weight) * rollingRssi + weight * currentRssi;
RSSI readings are inherently noisy, so this averaging gives a smoothed RSSI value to work with as a heuristic for proximity.
If no RSSI was read, then a sentinel value of 127 will be recorded.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.RemoteLockScreenState
histogram.summary: Whether a lock screen and a trust agent are enabled on the remote device (Android phone) for Easy Unlock. Recorded once per status update message from the remote device. A status update message is expected to be sent once when the secure channel between the local and the remote device is established, and also each time the user-presence status changes on the remote side.

histogram.name: EasyUnlock.StartupTimeFromSuspend
histogram.summary: The time it takes after resuming from a suspended state (ie. opening the Chromebook lid) to when a remote device is connected and a request is made. Note that it is possible for the remote device not to be present when resuming from suspend, and the device may be connected at a later time. Therefore, large values for this metric may not be too meaningful due to meddling users.

histogram.name: EphemeralTab.BottomSheet.CloseReason
histogram.summary: Records the reason that the BottomSheet-based Ephemeral Tab panel was closed. Recorded when the UX is hidden. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: EphemeralTab.CloseReason
histogram.summary: Records the reason that the Ephemeral Tab panel was closed. Recorded when the UX is hidden. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: EphemeralTab.Ctr
histogram.summary: Records whether the user fully opened the Ephemeral Tab panel when it was shown. Recorded when the UX is hidden. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: EphemeralTab.CtrPeek
histogram.summary: Records whether the user opened the Ephemeral Tab panel beyond peeking state. Recorded when the UX is hidden. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: EphemeralTab.DurationOpened
histogram.summary: Records the duration in milliseconds that the Ephemeral Tab was left open. Recorded when the UX is hidden. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: EphemeralTab.DurationPeeked
histogram.summary: Records the duration in milliseconds that the Ephemeral Tab was peeking. Recorded when the UX is hidden. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: ExclusiveAccess.BubbleReshowsPerSession.Fullscreen
histogram.summary: The number of times the fullscreen bubble was re-shown due to inactivity during a session of fullscreen mode (not including mouse or keyboard lock). If the mouse or keyboard is also locked while a re-show occurs, both this and BubbleReshowsPerSession.MouseLock and/or BubbleReshowsPerSession.KeyboardLock are incremented. Includes all types of fullscreen (user-triggered, extension-triggered and page-triggered). Recorded at the end of the session if the simplified-fullscreen-ui flag is enabled.

histogram.name: ExclusiveAccess.BubbleReshowsPerSession.KeyboardLock
histogram.summary: The number of times the keyboard lock exit bubble was re-shown during a session of keyboard lock mode. This occurs when the ExclusiveAccessMode inactivity timer fires (roughly every 15 minutes). If also in fullscreen while a re-show occurs both this and BubbleReshowsPerSession.Fullscreen are incremented in that scenario. Recorded at the end of the session if the simplified-fullscreen-ui flag is enabled.

histogram.name: ExclusiveAccess.BubbleReshowsPerSession.KeyboardLockForced
histogram.summary: The number of times the keyboard lock exit bubble was re-shown during a session of keyboard lock mode due to the user pressing the escape key repeatedly. This metric does not count reshows due to inactivity. Recorded at the end of the session if the simplified-fullscreen-ui flag is enabled.

histogram.name: ExclusiveAccess.BubbleReshowsPerSession.MouseLock
histogram.summary: The number of times the mouse lock bubble was re-shown due to inactivity during a session of mouse lock mode. If also in fullscreen while a re-show occurs, both this and BubbleReshowsPerSession.Fullscreen are incremented. Recorded at the end of the session if the simplified-fullscreen-ui flag is enabled.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.CatalogError
histogram.summary: If we find a bad catalog from the network, report which problems it had.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.CatalogRequestResult
histogram.summary: Results of the Explore Sites network request for a catalog.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.CatalogUpdateRequestSource
histogram.summary: The Explore Sites catalog can be requested in several code paths. This identifies which code path was used for the request.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.CategoryClick
histogram.summary:
The number of times the user clicked on a site in a category with the selected type on the Explore Sites page.
This histogram is of special interest to the chrome-analysis-team@. Do not change its semantics or retire it without talking to them first.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.ClickedNTPCategoryIndex
histogram.summary: 0-based index of a category tile on NTP which was clicked by the user. Indices are assigned by counting category tiles left-to-right, top-to-bottom as they appear on NTP. Recorded on click.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.ExploreSitesStore.StoreEvent
histogram.summary: Counts when the explore sites store is opened or closed.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.FetcherHttpResponseCode
histogram.summary: Http response code from ExploreSitesFetcher. Recorded every time the fetcher is finishing without network error and actually has HTTP response code. 2XX codes also included.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.FetcherNetErrorCode
histogram.summary: Net error results from ExploreSitesFetcher. Recorded every time the fetcher is finishing. OK and ABORTED are included.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.ImageDecoded
histogram.summary: Tracks the result of image decoding for the favicons.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.MonthlyHostCount
histogram.summary: Number of unique hosts visited by the user during the last 30 days. Reported at most once a week for all users on Android only, with a 5 second delay after startup. This is different from History.MonthlyHostCount which is reported for a percentage of startups, to avoid bias toward more active users.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.NavBackTime
histogram.summary: Recorded every time a user navigates out of the explore sites page and comes back to it within 30 seconds on the same tab. This is used to measure accidental clicks, where we expect users who navigate to the wrong page will navigate back to the ExploreSites page immediately afterward.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.NTPLoadingCatalogFromNetwork
histogram.summary: Recorded every time NTP is opened while ExploreSites feature is enabled. Indicates whether or not the local cached version of ExploreSites catalog was available or a network request was initiated to load one.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.RequestStatus
histogram.summary: Reported each time from the result callback of the ExploreSitesFetcher. Values include Success and several failure codes.

histogram.name: ExploreSites.SiteTilesClickIndex2
histogram.summary: The total index of the selected tile on the ExploreSites page. This measures how far down from the top it is, counting all the other tiles in cards above it. This assumes 10 tiles per category, which is set to the maximum of the tile counts of all existing variations of the ExploreSites page.

histogram.name: FactoryPingEmbargo.EndDateValidity
histogram.summary: Record the validity of |rlz_embargo_end_date| in RW_VPD. This is recorded when the VPD value is accessed, which may be multiple times in the same chrome invocation. This is not recorded when the VPD value is missing.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.ArcAppsCount
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used arc apps in the past 28 days.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.BorealisAppsCount
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used borealis apps in the past 28 days.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.ChromeBrowserEngagement.Duration
histogram.summary: Records the Chrome OS user Chrome browser usage in milliseconds. Reports current daily duration at the first session start on next day. This is only logged for active foreground time of Chrome browser. Ignores the time when video or audio is playing in the background, or Chrome browser is invisible.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.CrostiniAppsCount
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used crostini apps in the past 28 days.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.DeviceOwner
histogram.summary: Records whether the current primary user is the owner of device. Reports at the beginning of the first active session daily.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.EnabledExtensionsCount
histogram.summary: Records the number of non-component enabled regular browser extensions and themes around once per day, regardless of when they were last used.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.ExtensionAppsCount
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used extension apps in the past 28 days. Compared to FamilyUser.InstalledExtensionsCount, this metric only includes apps and excludes regular browser extensions.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.FamilyLinkUsersCount
histogram.summary: Records the number of family link users on a Chrome OS device at the beginning of the first active session daily.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.GaiaUsersCount
histogram.summary: Records the number of Gaia users on a Chrome OS device, at the beginning of the first active session daily for all user types except incognito session. The user count could be 0 if the managed device has ephemeral user policy.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.InstalledExtensionsCount
histogram.summary: Records the number of non-component installed regular browser extensions and themes around once per day, regardless of when they were last used.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.ManagedSiteList
histogram.summary: Records whether managed sites approved list and blocked list are enabled for currently active Family Link user. Reports at the beginning of the first active session daily. Ignores the reports during OOBE and sign out.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.NewUserAdded
histogram.summary: Reports NewUserAdded enum when a new Family Link user or regular user is successfully added to Chrome OS device. Other user types fall into the other bucket. Reports when the user session starts.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.OtherAppsCount
histogram.obsolete: Replaced with individual app types in M90.
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used apps in the past 28 days in a catch-all other category. Includes unknown, built-in, mac native, plugin vm, lacros, and remote apps.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.SessionEngagement.Duration
histogram.summary: Records the Chrome OS user session duration in milliseconds. Reports current daily duration at the first session start on next day. This is only logged for active usage time of device, determined by UsageTimeState::ACTIVE.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.SessionEngagement.Total
histogram.summary: Records the Chrome OS user engagement hour within the current day (0-23), total of weekday and weekend. Logged on UsageTimeStateNotifier::UsageTimeState changes to INACTIVE. Might report the same hour multiple times.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.SessionEngagement.Weekday
histogram.summary: Records the Chrome OS user engagement hour of day (0-23) on weekday. Logged on UsageTimeStateNotifier::UsageTimeState changes to INACTIVE. Might report the same hour multiple times.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.SessionEngagement.Weekend
histogram.summary: Records the Chrome OS user engagement hour of day (0-23) on weekend. Logged on UsageTimeStateNotifier::UsageTimeState changes to INACTIVE. Might report the same hour multiple times.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.TimeLimitPolicyTypes
histogram.summary: Records what time limit policy types are enabled for the currently active Family Link user. Enabling multiple policies would report multiple buckets to UMA. Reports at the beginning of the first active session daily.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.TotalAppsCount
histogram.obsolete: We only know the individual app type totals, not the overall total, after M90.
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the total number of recently used apps in the past 28 days.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.TotalUsersCount
histogram.obsolete: Removed in M90. Use FamilyUser.GaiaUsersCount instead.
histogram.summary: Records the number of users for all user types on a Chrome OS device at the beginning of the first active session daily.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.WebAppsCount
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used web apps in the past 28 days.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.WebFilterType
histogram.summary: Records the web filter type for currently active Family Link user. Reports at the beginning of the first active session daily. Ignores the reports during OOBE and sign out.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.{AppType}AppsCount2
histogram.summary: Around once per day, records the number of recently used {AppType} apps in the past day.

histogram.name: FamilyUser.{ExtensionStatus}ExtensionsCount2
histogram.summary: Records the number of non-component {ExtensionStatus} regular browser extensions and themes around once per day, regardless of when they were last used.

histogram.name: FaultTolerantHeap
histogram.summary: Records several bits of information about whether the Windows FaultTolerantHeap might be enabled. This is logged (from a delayed task) when the browser process starts up.

histogram.name: Favicon.OnDemandIconExistsInDb
histogram.summary: Records whether an icon already existed in the thumbnail DB when downloading an on-demand one. On-demand icons are the ones added to local cache without the user visiting the corresponding page.

histogram.name: Favicons.LargeIconService.BlacklistedURLMismatch
histogram.summary: Records the number of large icons that were fetched from the local cache (e.g. during NTP impression), where the URL (of the page or the icon) matches a hardcoded blacklist. Suspicious mismatches are reported as errors.

histogram.name: Favicons.LargeIconService.DownloadedSize
histogram.summary: Records the size (concretely the width) in pixel of the favicon downloaded from Google favicon server (size 0 denotes that download has failed).

histogram.name: Favicons.LargeIconService.FallbackSize
histogram.summary: Records the size (concretely the width) in pixel of the favicon that is used to generate a fallback style in the case when large enough favicon is not available (size 0 denotes that no favicon is available at all).

histogram.name: Feedback.HappinessTrackingSurvey.BubbleUsage
histogram.summary: Records how user interacts with Happiness Tracking Surveys (HaTS) bubble prompt which is shown for a subset of users. Each time when the bubble is shown, there should be one and only one enum type is recorded.

histogram.name: Feedback.HappinessTrackingSurvey.ShouldShowSurveyReason
histogram.summary: Records the first reason why the Happiness Tracking Surveys (HaTS) bubble was or was not shown. While the request to show may not meet multiple criteria, the first criterion is reported here.

histogram.name: Feedback.RequestSource
histogram.summary: Records the source that requested showing the feedback app.

histogram.name: FirstRun.IOSFirebaseConfigured
histogram.summary: Track whether Firebase is enabled or not at app startup.

histogram.name: FirstRun.LaunchSource
histogram.summary: Counts the number of times First Run experience was triggered by another application launching Chrome. This metric measures the effectiveness of Smart App Banner promotions on installation of Chrome.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.GoogleAppsInteraction
histogram.summary: Records when a user interacted with the Google Apps new user experience. We record both accept and reject but are not recording when a user ignored the prompt completely. Users can ignore this prompt by closing the tab or navigating away, we record when the prompt is shown.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.GoogleAppsSelection
histogram.summary: Records what Google apps were selected as part of the Google Apps New User Experience. Histogram is only recorded when a user accepts the prompt to add Google Apps.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.LandingPageInteraction
histogram.summary: Records when a user interacted with the landing page of the onboarding process. We record that the page was seen and what action the user took.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.NtpBackgroundInteraction
histogram.summary: Records when a user interacts with the NTP Backgrounds new user experience. We record the number of times the page is seen, how they interacted with the page (i.e. interacted with the options and buttons), and through what method they leave the page (i.e, confirm, cancel, neither). The new user experience should only be shown once to new profiles.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.NtpBackgroundLoadTime
histogram.summary: Records the time taken to load a NTP background image for preview. This is recorded when a user clicks on a background to preview and the full-size version of the background finishes loading.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.SetAsDefaultInteraction
histogram.summary: Records when a user interacted with the set default page of the onboarding process. We record that the page was seen and what action the user took.

histogram.name: FirstRun.NewUserExperience.SignInInterstitialInteraction
histogram.summary: Records when a user interacted with the sign in interstitial of the onboarding process. We record that the page was seen and what action the user took.

histogram.name: FirstRun.Sentinel.Created
histogram.summary: Result of sentinel file has been written.

histogram.name: FirstRun.Sentinel.CreatedFileError
histogram.summary: File error when the sentinel file was not written.

histogram.name: FirstRun.SignIn
histogram.summary: Result of the sign in flow during first run on iOS.

histogram.name: FirstUserAction.BackgroundTime
histogram.summary:
WARNING: The list of actions used to identify new tasks hasn't been attentively updated for several years (as of 2017). Some actions that should likely be considered new tasks are probably missing. Take this histogram with a grain of salt. Was expired for M85, M86.
The amount of time (in seconds) that the app was in the background before the user started it

histogram.name: FirstUserAction.HandsetUserActionType
histogram.summary:
WARNING: The list of actions used to identify new tasks hasn't been attentively updated for several years (as of 2017). Some actions that should likely be considered new tasks are probably missing. Take this histogram with a grain of salt. Was expired for M77-M86.
On handsets, the type of the first user action performed after the app was started or unbackgrounded.

histogram.name: FirstUserAction.TabletUserActionType
histogram.summary:
WARNING: The list of actions used to identify new tasks hasn't been attentively updated for several years (as of 2017). Some actions that should likely be considered new tasks are probably missing. Take this histogram with a grain of salt. Was expired for M82-M86.
On tablets, the type of the first user action performed after the app was started or unbackgrounded.

histogram.name: FontFallback.GetLinkedFonts.CacheMissTiming
histogram.summary: Time to retrieve the fallback fonts on the system when not found in cache.

histogram.name: FontFallback.GetLinkedFonts.FontCount
histogram.summary: The amount of font returned for a given font family.

histogram.name: FontFallback.GetLinkedFonts.Timing
histogram.summary: Time to retrieve the fallback fonts on the system.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.DuplicateFontCount
histogram.summary: The number of duplicate fonts returned by system APIs. This is recorded when fonts are enumerated to be returned to script as a result of a call to the Font Access API.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.Dwrite.FamilyCount
histogram.summary: Records the number of font families observed by the font enumeration cache as part of the Font Access API.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.Dwrite.GetSystemFontCollectionResult
histogram.summary: Records errors returned when obtaining the list of system fonts from DirectWrite's GetSystemFontCollection.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.Dwrite.MostFrequentEnumerationFailure
histogram.summary: Records the most frequent failure to obtain metadata for a font family when enumerating fonts as part of the Font Access API. Recorded in FontEnumerationCacheWin when all fonts have been enumerated. Values are Windows HRESULT error codes, and also includes custom values specific to this implementation.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.Fontconfig.DuplicateFontCount
histogram.obsolete: Removed in M86 in favor of Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.DuplicateFontCount.
histogram.summary: The number of duplicate fonts returned by fontconfig.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.Fontconfig.FontCount
histogram.summary: The number of fonts returned by fontconfig.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationCache.Fontconfig.IncompleteFontCount
histogram.summary: The number of fonts whose name table entries could not be read.

histogram.name: Fonts.AccessAPI.EnumerationTime
histogram.summary: Time spent enumerating fonts.

histogram.name: ForceDiceMigration.RevokeTokenAction
histogram.summary: Tracks revoke actions taken by the account reconcilior to force Dice migration. To enforce consistency, the reconcilior may invalidate the primary account or revoke one or more secondary account tokens, if no equivalent valid gaia cookie exist for those accounts.

histogram.name: Gaia.AuthFetcher.ListAccounts.NetErrorCodes
histogram.summary: Reports the network error code for requests to the ListAccounts Gaia endpoint.

histogram.name: Gaia.BadRequestTypeForOAuth2AccessToken
histogram.summary: Detailed error type in bad requests for OAuth2 access tokens. Recorded when a HTTP 400 is received in response to a access token request.

histogram.name: Gaia.ResponseCodesForOAuth2AccessToken
histogram.summary: URLFetcher response codes for OAuth2AccessToken. Positive values are HTTP status codes, negative values are network error codes. Recorded on responses to OAuth access token requests.

histogram.name: Gamepad.KnownGamepadConnectedWithId
histogram.summary: Records an integer value that can be used to identify a connected gamepad device. The value is constructed from the 16-bit vendor ID in the high-order bytes and the 16-bit product ID in the low-order bytes, then cast to a 32-bit signed integer. The GamepadVendorProduct enum lists IDs for several popular gamepads but is incomplete. To identify a device not included in the enum, convert back to the vendor/product IDs and look up the human-friendly product name in go/gamepad-ids. This histogram records a new entry when a device with a vendor and product ID matching a known gaming input device is detected during Gamepad API enumeration.

histogram.name: Gamepad.UnknownGamepadConnected
histogram.summary: Records an enumeration value identifying the active data fetcher when a fetcher enumerates a device that is not on the list of known gamepads, but is recognized as a gamepad by the fetcher.

histogram.name: GData.AuthSuccess
histogram.owner: Please list the metric's owners. Add more owner tags as needed.
histogram.summary: Result of the authentication for Drive.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Activated
histogram.summary: Overscroll gesture was made beyond a threshold big enough to regard it as a valid gesture navigation i.e. at least 1/3 of the arrow puck is visible. Similar to 'Triggered' but is used in pair with 'Cancelled' on M81 forward to measure cancellation rate. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Cancelled
histogram.summary: Overscroll gestures that were cancelled before they were completed. Similar to 'Abandoned' but is used in pair with 'Activated' on M81 forward to measure cancellation rate. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Completed
histogram.summary: Navigations that were triggered due to completed overscroll gesture. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Reversed
histogram.summary: Overscroll gesture was made to trigger navigation, but within 3 seconds user used overscroll gesture to navigate back to the page. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Sheet.Peeked
histogram.summary: Overscroll gesture was made to trigger navigation bottom sheet to peeked state. Peek state can be entered and exited more than once in a sequence of overscroll gesture (until user lifts his finger). They are recorded as just one event per sequence. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Sheet.Selected
histogram.summary: Index of the entries in the navigation bottom sheet that user tapped. Negative means navigating backward, positive forward. Zero index means that the user chose "Show full history".

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Sheet.Used
histogram.summary: User tapped one of the entries in the expanded navigation bottom sheet to navigate to other page. Implemented for Android.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Sheet.Viewed
histogram.summary: Overscroll gesture was made to trigger navigation bottom sheet to expanded state where the whole list of history items are presented.

histogram.name: GestureNavigation.Type
histogram.summary: Gesture navigation type. It can be either Chrome's own gesture UI that supports back and forward navigation or OS-provided default system gesture navigation that supports only back action on both left and right edge. This is recorded on Chrome startup at the feature component initialization.

histogram.name: Gpu.GL.GetErrorDuration.GLImageEGL.BindTexImage
histogram.summary: The time that elapsed for a call to glGetError to complete while trying to bind a GLImageEGL to a texture. The goal is to measure the impact of the potential sync barrier that glGetError represents. Only reported for platforms supporting high resolution clocks.

histogram.name: Gpu.GL.GetErrorResult.GLImageEGL.BindTexImage
histogram.summary: Whether glGetError actually returned an error while trying to bind a GLImageEGL to a texture. The goal is to evaluate how often the call to glGetError might actually serve its purpose.

histogram.name: Gpu.GL.ProgramBuildTime
histogram.summary: The time that elapsed between a call to glCreateProgram and the call to query GL_LINK_STATUS via glGetProgramiv in Skia's GrGLInterface. This encompasses the creation of the vertex, fragment, and geometry shaders, their compilation, and their linking. This is called for every program created by Skia via the GrGLInterface.

histogram.name: Gpu.Mac.Backpressure
histogram.summary: The time that the GPU's main CPU thread spends waiting for previous frames' GPU work to complete. Recorded at every frame.

histogram.name: Gpu.Metal.TestShaderCompileTime
histogram.summary: Compiling a MTLLibrary will sometimes hang forever. When initializing the gpu process, a test shader is compiled to see if the MTLCompilerService is responding or not. This records the time that it took for the compile to succeeded, up to 1 minute. After 1 minute, a timeout sentinel value of 3 minutes is reported.

histogram.name: Gpu.Metal.TestShaderLinkTime
histogram.summary: Linking a MTLRenderPipelineState will sometimes hang forever. When initializing the GPU process, a test shader is compiled to see if the MTLCompilerService is responding or not. This records the time that it took for the compile to succeeded, up to 1 minute. After 1 minute, a timeout sentinel value of 3 minutes is reported.

histogram.name: Gpu.MetalProxy.NewLibraryTime
histogram.summary: The time that it takes to create a new MTLLibrary, including all retries. Recorded after every call to -[MTLDeviceProxy newLibraryWithSource:] completes.

histogram.name: Gpu.MetalProxy.NewRenderPipelineStateTime
histogram.summary: The time that it takes to create a new MTLRenderPipelineState, including all retries. Recorded after every call to -[MTLDeviceProxy newRenderPipelineStateWithDescriptor:] completes.

histogram.name: Graphics.PresentationTimestamp.InvalidBeforeSwap
histogram.summary: Presentation timestamp comes from the driver when showing a display frame on screen. These timestamps could be invalid, and be earlier than the swap time. This metric records how much time before the swap-time such invalid timestamps are. If the presentation timestamp is after the swap-time, then this metric is not recorded.

histogram.name: Graphics.PresentationTimestamp.InvalidFromFuture
histogram.summary: Presentation timestamp comes from the driver when showing a display frame on screen. These timestamps can sometimes be in the future. This metric records how far in the future these timestamps can be. If the timestamp is not in the future, then this metric is not recorded.

histogram.name: Graphics.PresentationTimestamp.LargePresentationDelta
histogram.summary: Measures very large (more than 3 minutes) delay in presenting display frames. Presentation timestamp comes from the driver when showing a display frame on screen. There are times when the presentation can be delayed a long time. This metric reports how often this can happen. This is reported only if the presentation takes 3 minutes or more.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.95pctPercentDroppedFrames_1sWindow
histogram.summary:
The percent dropped frame is calculated for each sliding window of 1 second length and added to a histogram, and then the 95 percentile of that histogram is reported as 95pctPercentDroppedFrames_1sWindow.
The sliding windows cover the duration of page-load (From start of page-load until user navigates away, or closes the tab/chrome, or when app goes to background). Note that this means that this metric will bias toward tabs that are closed more quickly, and might underreport tabs that remain open for a long duration.
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Checkerboarding
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of frames that were shown with checkerboards during a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.). Note that this is only recorded for sequences of length > 4.
Checkerboarding is measured by tracking the number of times checkerboard frames are displayed (as opposed to the number of checkerboard frames produced), since the same checkerboard frame can be displayed more than once.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Diagnostic.DiscardedDependentCount
histogram.summary:
Diagnostic metric to measure how many dependent reporters have been discarded.
The reporters might be dependant on another reporter (when having partial updates) but if the number of dependents go over a limit we would discard them earlier. This metric count how many of such reporters been discarded earlier than expected as a result of outstanding number of dependent reporters. The metric will be reported at the end of each frame if there has been any discarded dependent reporters.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Diagnostic.DroppedFrameAfterScrollStart.Frames
histogram.summary:
Diagnostic metric to measure how long after scroll-start a frame is dropped.
For every frame dropped during a scroll, this metric reports how long after scroll started the frame dropped (in number of vsyncs).

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Diagnostic.DroppedFrameAfterScrollStart.Time
histogram.summary:
Diagnostic metric to measure how long after scroll-start a frame is dropped.
For every frame dropped during a scroll, this metric reports how long after scroll started the frame dropped (in milliseconds).

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Diagnostic.ReadSharedMemoryDuration
histogram.summary:
Diagnostic metric to track how long it takes to read the smoothness data from shared memory.
Warning: This metric may include reports from clients with low-resolution clocks (i.e. on Windows, ref. |TimeTicks::IsHighResolution()|). Such reports will cause this metric to have an abnormal distribution.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Diagnostic.ReadSharedMemoryUKMSuccess
histogram.summary: Diagnostic metric to track how often reading the smoothness data for UKM from the shared memory (using atomic memcpy) fails (or succeeds).

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.FrameSequenceLength
histogram.summary: Counts the number of frames expected during a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.).

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Jank
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of janks for a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.). This is reported in various sub-metrics with suffixes describing the type of the sequence (e.g. TouchScroll etc.).
Jank is measured by tracking the number of abrupt increases in frame presentation interval, divided by the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. The lower this number is, the less the smoothness varies over time.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.MaxPercentDroppedFrames_1sWindow
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of dropped frames for in a 1 second sliding window.
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.MaxStale
histogram.summary:
Tracks the maximum staleness value for all presentations for a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.). This is reported in various sub-metrics with suffixes describing the type of the sequence (e.g. TouchScroll etc.).
Typically, a frame presentation is expected to last at least one vsync cycle, plus any number of additional vsync cycles if no updates are expected duration that time. If the presentation interval is prolonged due to reasons other than listed above, then that prolonged portion will be considered staleness for that frame.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentDroppedFrames
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of dropped frames for a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.). This is reported in various sub-metrics with suffixes describing the type of the sequence (e.g. TouchScroll etc.).
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentDroppedFrames.AllAnimations
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of dropped frames for a particular sequence of frames for all animations. This metric is reported for all animations (e.g. comositor-driven animations, main-thread driven animations, and raf-driven animations).
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentDroppedFrames.AllInteractions
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of dropped frames for a particular sequence of frames where a user-input (e.g. scroll, pinch) is active. This metric is reported for all sources of user-input (i.e. both touchscreen and touchpad/mouse-wheel).
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentDroppedFrames.AllSequences
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of dropped frames for a particular sequence of frames. This metric is reported for all animations and all interactions.
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentMissedDeadlineFrames
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of frames that missed the deadline for a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.). This is reported in various sub-metrics with suffixes describing the type of the sequence (e.g. TouchScroll etc.).
PercentMissedDeadlineFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were displayed on screen but missed the vsync interval.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentMissedDeadlineFrames.AllAnimations
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of frames that missed the deadline for a particular sequence of frames for all animations. This metric is reported for all animations (e.g. comositor-driven animations, main-thread driven animations, and raf-driven animations).
PercentMissedDeadlineFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were displayed on screen but missed the vsync interval.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentMissedDeadlineFrames.AllInteractions
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of frames that missed the deadline for a particular sequence of frames where a user-input (e.g. scroll, pinch) is active. This metric is reported for all sources of user-input (i.e. both touchscreen and touchpad/mouse-wheel).
PercentMissedDeadlineFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were displayed on screen but missed the vsync interval.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PercentMissedDeadlineFrames.AllSequences
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of frames that missed the deadline for a particular sequence of frames. This metric is reported for all animations and all interactions.
PercentMissedDeadlineFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were displayed on screen but missed the vsync interval.
Note that this metric is reported only when there are sufficient number of frames (>= 100). If there are sequences with fewer frames, then these are aggregated until there are enough frames to produce the metric.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PerSession.95pctPercentDroppedFrames_1sWindow
histogram.summary:
Tracks the 95th percentile of dropped frames percent of a sliding window of 1 second. The metric is reported once per page-load when the page closes. If there are fewer than 20 sliding windows for calculating 95th percentile, the max value will be used instead of 95th percentile.
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PerSession.AveragePercentDroppedFrames
histogram.summary:
Tracks the percent of dropped frames. The metric is reported once per page-load when the page closes.
AveragePercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.PerSession.MaxPercentDroppedFrames_1sWindow
histogram.summary:
Tracks the Max of dropped frames percent of a sliding window of 1 second. The metric is reported once per page-load when the page closes.
PercentDroppedFrames is measured by tracking the number of frames which were not displayed on screen out of the total number of frames expected to be produced and displayed. In other words, the lower this number is, the smoother experience.

histogram.name: Graphics.Smoothness.Stale
histogram.summary:
Tracks the staleness value for each frame presentation for a particular sequence of frames (e.g. during scroll, animation, etc.). This is reported in various sub-metrics with suffixes describing the type of the sequence (e.g. TouchScroll etc.).
Typically, a frame presentation is expected to last at least one vsync cycle, plus any number of additional vsync cycles if no updates are expected duration that time. If the presentation interval is prolonged due to reasons other than listed above, then that prolonged portion will be considered staleness.
Note that the reporting of this metric occurs as soon as a frame is presented, and is not affected by the length of the frame sequence.

histogram.name: GraphicsPipeline.ReceivedBeginFrame
histogram.summary:
The amount of time it takes for the BeginFrame to travel to the Client from the DisplayCompositor.
Note that this metrics is only recorded on clients on which a high-resolution clock is available

histogram.name: GraphicsPipeline.SubmitCompositorFrameAfterBeginFrame
histogram.summary:
How long the client takes to prepare a compositor frame after receiving a BeginFrameArgs.
Note that this is only recorded on clients on which a high-resolution clock is available.

histogram.name: GridTabSwitcher.DirtySpan
